header.title: Abramelin's Magickal Word Squares Compiled and Corrected for the First Time

central_thesis: This document presents the first comprehensive compilation and correction of the Abramelin word squares in English, derived from George Dehn's German translation of the original manuscripts. The author identifies and rectifies numerous transcription errors, transpositions, inversions, and mislabeling that have historically corrupted these magical tools, offering a corrected resource for practitioners and scholars.

structure_content.chapter_title: Introduction and Methodology
structure_content.summary: Leitch outlines the provenance of the squares (Dehn's German translation vs. Mathers' French recension) and details the extensive errors found in prior versions. He explains his corrective methodology, which combines pattern recognition, intuition, and linguistic analysis across Hebrew, Greek, and Latin lexicons, noting specific challenges like 'c' vs. 'e' and 'f' vs. 's' confusions. The author emphasizes the document's role in making these corrected squares available for the first time in English.

structure_content.chapter_title: A Brief Overview of Word Squares
structure_content.summary: This section defines the various types and aspects of magical word squares relevant to the Abramelin tradition: Acrostic ('Staircase') where words read the same forward and downward; Double Acrostic where readings differ; 'Perfect' Double Acrostic (like SATOR) where words read identically in all four directions; 'Frame' as a word outlining the square; 'Central Cross' (for odd-numbered squares, often a palindrome); and the significance of 'Palindromes' and 'Reflected Palindromes'. The principle of 'Unstandardized Spelling' for phonetic accuracy over strict orthography is also introduced.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 1: To Discover Past and Future Things, but Not Against the Will of God.
structure_content.summary: This chapter provides specific word squares for the purpose of divining past and future events, with a caveat that such knowledge should not oppose divine will. Examples include squares for 'To Know Things Past' (1/1) and various applications for 'Future Things' (1/2, 1/3), including 'To Know Future Things in War' (1/4).

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 2: To Have Reports on Doubtful Things.
structure_content.summary: This chapter lists word squares designed to obtain clarity and information regarding uncertain or doubtful matters. Specific squares are provided without further operational details within this document, implying their use in rituals to resolve ambiguities.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 3: To Make Every Spirit Appear.
structure_content.summary: This chapter provides word squares intended for the evocation of spirits into various forms. Squares are categorized by the desired appearance, such as 'In the Shape of a Dragon' (3/1), 'In Human Shape' (3/2), 'In Animal Shape' (3/3), and 'In Bird Shape' (3/4).

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 4: To Create Visions.
structure_content.summary: This chapter contains word squares used to induce visions. The context of these visions varies, including apparitions 'In Mirrors, Glass and Crystals' (4/1), 'In Caves, Vaults, Crypts and Grottos Underground' (4/2), 'In the Air' (4/3), 'In Jewels and Rings' (4/4), 'In Beeswax and Through Writing' (4/5), 'Through Fire' (4/6), 'In the Moon' (4/7), 'In Water' (4/8), and 'In the Hand' (4/9).

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 5: To obtain Familiar Spirits, Bound or Free, and to Send Them Away.
structure_content.summary: This chapter is dedicated to the acquisition and dismissal of familiar spirits. The word squares facilitate the appearance of these spirits in specific forms, such as 'In the Form of a Giant' (5/1), 'As a Page' (5/2), 'As a Soldier' (5/3), 'In the Form of a Flower' (5/4), 'As an Old Man' (5/5), 'As a Rider' (5/6), 'As a Negro in Appearance' (5/7), 'As an Eagle' (5/8), 'As a Snake' (5/9), 'As a Lion' (5/10), 'As a Dog' (5/11), and 'As a Monkey' (5/12).

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 6: For Working Mines.
structure_content.summary: This chapter outlines word squares for various operations related to mining. These include preventing 'Shafts do not Collapse in Mines' (6/1), 'To Show the Location of Gold or Silver Veins' (6/2), 'To do all Sorts of Mining Work' (6/3), 'To do Mining with Tunnels' (6/4), 'To Take Water Out of Mines and Shafts' (6/5), 'For the Spirits to Bring Wood for Smelting' (6/6), 'To Purify the Ore' (6/7), and 'To do Various Mining Works' (6/8).

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 7: To Have the Spirits Perform Alchemical Work.
structure_content.summary: This chapter provides word squares to direct spirits in alchemical tasks. These operations involve commanding spirits 'To Have the Spirits Bring Forth All Sorts of Metals Through Chemical Work' (7/1), 'To Have the Spirits Do All Sorts of Chemical Work' (7/2), and 'To Learn All Sorts of Alchemical Arts From the Spirits' (7/3).

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 8: To Make or Prevent Storms.
structure_content.summary: This chapter details word squares for weather manipulation, specifically 'To Make Hail' (8/1), 'To Make a Heavy, Short Shower' (8/2), 'To Make Snow and Ice' (8/3), and 'To Make a Thunderstorm' (8/4).

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 9: To Transform People into Animals and Animals into People.
structure_content.summary: This chapter presents word squares for transfiguration. The operations include transforming 'People into Donkeys' (9/1), 'People into Deer' (9/2), 'Animals into People' (9/3), 'People into Wild Pigs' (9/4), 'People into Dogs' (9/5), 'People into Wolves' (9/6), and 'Animals into Stone' (9/7).

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 10: To Prevent and Remove All Other Magick.
structure_content.summary: This chapter offers word squares designed for protection against and reversal of various magical effects. Operations include 'To Heal Magickal Sicknesses' (10/1), 'To Prevent Magickal Storms' (10/2), 'When a Magician is in the Air Making a Cloud, so That he Falls to Earth' (10/3), 'Expose Hidden Appearances' (10/4), 'Expose Hidden Magicians' (10/5), 'To Make a Magician's Soldiers Disappear' (10/6), and 'Hold This Square in Your Hand to Prevent Magick From Working' (10/7).

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 11: To Obtain Lost Books, Hidden Manuscripts, Etc.
structure_content.summary: This chapter provides word squares for the recovery of hidden or lost textual knowledge. The squares are categorized for finding 'Astronomical Books' (11/1), 'Magickal Books' (11/2), and 'Pharmacopeia' (11/3).

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 12: To Discover the Hidden Plans and Plots of a Person.
structure_content.summary: This chapter contains word squares for uncovering concealed intentions or schemes of individuals. Applications include discovering 'Secrets From Letters or Talk' (12/1), 'Secrets From Words' (12/2), 'Hidden Works of a Person' (12/3), 'Secret War Plans' (12/4), 'To Discover Sexual Activity' (12/5), 'The Hidden Riches and Treasures of a Person' (12/6), and 'The Hidden Arts of a Person' (12/7).

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 13: To Make a Dead Person Walk for Seven Years.
structure_content.summary: This chapter is dedicated to animating the dead for a prolonged period. The word squares are divided by time-frames of operation, including 'From Sunrise to Noon' (13/1), 'From Noon to Sunset' (13/2), 'From Sunset to Midnight' (13/3), and 'From Midnight to Sunrise' (13/4).

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 14: For Invisibility.
structure_content.summary: This chapter provides a series of word squares, one for each 'Hour' (14/1 through 14/12), intended for achieving invisibility. The specific mechanics of how each hour's square contributes to the overall effect are not detailed within this text.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 15: That the Spirits Bring All Sorts of Food and Drink.
structure_content.summary: This chapter lists word squares for the procurement of various provisions through spiritual agency. These include squares for 'Wine' (15/1), 'Meat' (15/2), 'Bread' (15/3), 'Fish' (15/4), and 'Cheese' (15/5).

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 16: To Recover Treasures.
structure_content.summary: This chapter contains word squares for locating and recovering hidden valuables. The squares are categorized by the type of treasure, such as 'Jewelery' (16/1), 'Silver' (16/2), 'Necklaces' (16/3), 'Jewels' (16/4), 'Treasures in General' (16/5, 16/6, 16/7, 16/8, 16/9, 16/13, 16/16), 'Coins' (16/11), 'Especially Gold' (16/14, 16/17), and 'Money' (16/15, 16/18), and 'Jewels' (16/19, 16/20).

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 17: Traveling in the Air.
structure_content.summary: This chapter presents word squares for enabling aerial travel. The squares specify different modes of transportation, including 'On a Ship' (17/1), 'On a Cloak' (17/2), 'On a Cloud' (17/3, 17/4), 'On a Stick' (17/5), and 'On a Wagon' (17/6).

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 18: Healing Sicknesses.
structure_content.summary: This chapter provides word squares for the remediation of various ailments. The squares target specific health conditions, such as 'Leprosy' (18/1, 18/2), 'Pimples and Ulcers' (18/3), 'Plague' (18/4), 'Stroke' (18/5), 'Fever' (18/6), 'Uterine Diseases' (18/7, 18/8), 'Dizziness' (18/9), 'Intestinal Colic' (18/10), and 'Wounds' (18/11).

structure_content.summary: This chapter contains word squares designed to foster various types of relationships and affections. Squares address connections 'With a Bride' (19/1), 'With a Bridegroom' (19/2, 19/18), 'Courting' (19/3), 'From a Particular Young Girl' (19/4), 'From a Particular Judge' (19/5), 'From a Widow' (19/6), 'From a Married Woman' (19/7), 'From an Engaged Woman' (19/8), 'From a Particular Youth' (19/9), 'From a Particular Prince' (19/10), 'For Peace in General' (19/11), 'For Friendship in General' (19/12), 'For the Love of a Particular Virgin' (19/13), 'With a Woman' (19/14), 'To be Loved by a Priest' (19/15), 'For the Love of a Lord' (19/16), 'With a Famous Man' (19/17), 'To be Wanted and Attractive' (19/19), and 'For Adultery in General' (19/20).

structure_content.summary: This chapter details word squares for inciting or resolving conflicts and ill will. Operations include 'To Start Fights and Battles' (20/1), 'To Shoot Accurately- in General' (20/2), 'To Commence Quarrels in General' (20/3), 'For Wrestling in General' (20/4), 'To Quieten the Gossip' (20/5), 'To Make Enmity' (20/6, 20/11, 20/12, 20/18, 20/19), 'Against Gossip' (20/9), 'To Stir Up Vengeance' (20/17, 20/20), 'To Commence War in General' (20/10), 'To Make a Fighter Unlucky' (20/13), 'To Make Differences Between Man and Wife' (20/14), 'Cause Vengeance' (20/15), and 'To Make Discord and Hate Between Two Friends' (20/16).

structure_content.summary: This chapter provides word squares for changing one's outward form. The appearances include 'Into an Old Man' (21/1), 'Into an Old Woman' (21/2), 'Into a Youngster' (21/3), 'Into a Young Girl' (21/4), 'Into a Boy' (21/5), and 'Into a Man with a Beard' (21/6).

structure_content.summary: This chapter outlines word squares for inducing various illnesses. The targets or types of sicknesses include those affecting 'Children' (22/1), 'Farm Animals' (22/2), 'On the Liver' (22/3), 'On the Sex Organs' (22/4), 'On the Heart' (22/5), and 'On the Neck' (22/6).

structure_content.summary: This chapter presents word squares for the destruction or dismantling of structures. Operations include collapsing 'To Collapse a House' (23/1), 'Walls' (23/2), 'Lift Off Roofs' (23/3), and 'Whole Buildings' (23/4).

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 24: For the Return of Things.
structure_content.summary: This chapter offers word squares for the recovery of lost or stolen items. The squares are for the return of 'Jewels' (24/1), 'Money' (24/2), 'Everything' (24/3, 24/4, 24/6), and 'Livestock' (24/5).

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 25: To Stay and Move Around Under Water.
structure_content.summary: This chapter provides word squares dedicated to magical operations related to aquatic environments, specifically for enabling one 'To Stay and Move Around Under Water' (25/1, 25/2).

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 26: To Open and Close Locks Without a Key.
structure_content.summary: This chapter details word squares for magically manipulating various types of restraints and barriers. The squares are for 'Door Opening' (26/1), 'Dissolving Chains' (26/2), 'Opening Bolts' (26/3), 'Opening Locks' (26/4), and 'Opening Jails' (26/5).

structure_content.summary: This chapter lists word squares for financial assistance, particularly during difficult times. The squares specify different denominations or types of currency, such as 'Gold Coins' (28/1), 'Medium Coins' (28/2), 'Ordinary Silver' (28/3), and 'Small Coins' (28/4).

structure_content.summary: This chapter provides word squares for the manifestation of military personnel and equipment. Operations include making 'A Whole Army Corps Appear' (29/1), 'To Have all Kinds of Soldiers Standing, Ready to Fight' (29/2), and 'To Make a Siege Appear in Front of a Town' (29/3).

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 30: To Have the Spirits Perform Music, Singing and Juggling.
structure_content.summary: This chapter details word squares for commanding spirits to perform various entertainments. These include 'Music and Songs' (30/1), having spirits 'Appear as Monkeys and Perform all Sorts of Strange Dances' (30/2), for 'All Sorts of Music From Stringed Instruments' (30/3), and for 'Spirits- Appearing as Monkeys- Perform Strange Acrobatics and Juggling' (30/4).

key_concepts.definition: A grid of letters where a word reads the same horizontally (first row) and vertically (first column), also referred to as a 'Staircase' square.
A grid of letters where the word reading horizontally (first row) is different from the word reading vertically (first column).
A specific type of word square where the central word (or entire square) reads the same forward, downward, backward, and upward (e.g., SATOR square).
A single word that is written around the entire circumference of a word square, forming its outer boundary.

A feature found only in odd-numbered word squares, consisting of a single word (typically a palindrome) written horizontally and vertically through the center of the square, intersecting at its midpoint.
A word, phrase, or sequence that reads the same backward as forward. Palindromes are considered particularly desirable in magical word squares due to their inherent symmetry and stability.

A specific type of palindrome where a smaller word is written forward and then backward in mirror reflection, creating a longer, often more 'mystical-looking' palindrome (e.g., HELLO becoming HELLOLLEH).

A principle in magical word square construction where strict, modern orthography is not required. Words can be abbreviated, extended, or altered phonetically to fit the square, especially when dealing with transliterated languages like Hebrew or Greek, provided the original phonetic value is maintained and the square remains decipherable.

The systematic examination of the etymology and phonetic properties of words within the squares, primarily from Biblical Hebrew, Greek, and Latin lexicons. This analysis aids in correcting corrupted squares, understanding their magical intent, and confirming phonetic integrity despite unstandardized spelling.

practical_system.description: The practical system presented by Leitch is a corrected compendium of the magical word squares from the Book of Abramelin, intended as operative tools for a vast range of magical operations. Each square is a sigil-like construct designed to achieve a specific magical effect or call forth particular entities, as detailed by the chapter titles. While this document is a compilation and correction, not an instructional manual, it implicitly forms the core toolkit for a system of ceremonial magic. The practitioner is expected to utilize these squares in rituals corresponding to the chapter headings, such as evoking spirits, manipulating weather, transforming appearances, discovering hidden knowledge, or healing ailments. The precise methods of charging, activating, or deploying these squares in ritual are assumed to be known or found in the broader Abramelin tradition.

relevant_quotes.text: As I placed Abramelin's words into their grids, I discovered a large number of errors. (Most of them apparently from the original manuscript, and not the fault of Mr. Dehn or Mr. Guth!)

Out of 242 squares, I have found approximately 156 in need of correction- not counting several instances where labels were applied to the wrong squares. Only one square in the entire set was irreparable.

Proper spelling is not necessary for magickal word-squares. Especially when using languages such as Greek and Hebrew, one is dealing with transliterations anyway. One may shrink, stretch or spell the words in nearly any manner to make them fit the square. Only one rule restricts this- the word must be phonetically like the original. A square should be decipherable by other scholars, even hundreds of years into the future.

In many cases, the linguistic 'decoding' of a square has resulted in further corrections to its lettering. I have nearly completed the Hebrew analysis (save for a few squares that have eluded me, and may not turn out to be Hebrew at all), and some of the Greek and Latin as well. Fortunately, the Abramelin squares are overwhelmingly based upon Hebrew, so I do not expect any further significant corrections to the squares' lettering.

critical_analysis.relevance: This work is highly relevant for both academic scholars and practical magicians operating within the Western Esoteric tradition, particularly those studying the grimoire tradition of the Book of Abramelin. By providing corrected versions of the word squares, Leitch addresses a long-standing issue of textual corruption that has hindered accurate study and practice. His meticulous methodology, combining pattern analysis with linguistic rigor, sets a new standard for grimoire scholarship. The document acts as a vital corrective, facilitating more effective magical operations and deeper philological understanding of the source material. It highlights the importance of original source material and careful transliteration in magical texts.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience consists of advanced practitioners of Ceremonial Magic and Grimoire traditions, particularly those who engage with the Book of Abramelin for practical work. Additionally, it is invaluable for academic researchers, philologists, and historians of Western Esotericism who study magical texts, their transmission, and linguistic underpinnings. The technical nature of the corrections and the focus on linguistic accuracy suggest a readership with a foundational understanding of occult terminology and scholarly research methods.
